message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The impaired abduction of the right arm and the ability to raise the arm above the head after passive abduction suggests a supraspinatus muscle dysfunction. This muscle is innervated by the suprascapular nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inability to actively abduct the arm but being able to passively do so suggests subacromial impingement syndrome. Among the options, only the suprascapular nerve innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the arm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with pain in his right shoulder and difficulty lifting his right arm, indicating that there may be damage or dysfunction in the supraspinatus muscle. This muscle is innervated by the suprascapular nerve, making option (A) the most likely choice. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is involved in shoulder abduction but not specifically impaired in this case. The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid muscle and the upper subscapular nerve innervates the subscapularis muscle, neither of which is specifically involved in the patient's impaired active abduction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to actively abduct his right arm from 0 to 15 degrees but is able to raise his arm above his head after passive abduction suggests supraspinatus muscle dysfunction. Supraspinatus muscle is innervated by the suprascapular nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inability to actively abduct the right arm but being able to do so passively suggests a supraspinatus muscle dysfunction. The supraspinatus muscle is innervated by the suprascapular nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s difficulty in active abduction but improved ability after passive abduction is suggestive of a supraspinatus muscle tear. The supraspinatus muscle is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. All other options do not innervate the supraspinatus muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The right shoulder pain and impaired active abduction suggest supraspinatus muscle dysfunction, which is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, the axillary nerve innervates the deltoid muscle, and the upper subscapular nerve innervates the subscapularis muscle, but these muscles are not responsible for impaired active abduction in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The inability to actively raise the right arm suggests a supraspinatus muscle dysfunction, which is innervated by the suprascapular nerve. The other nerves listed do not innervate the supraspinatus muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The impaired active abduction and the fact that passive abduction allows for full range of motion suggests a supraspinatus muscle tear. The supraspinatus muscle is innervated by the suprascapular nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings suggest a rotator cuff injury, specifically a supraspinatus muscle tear. The supraspinatus muscle is innervated by the suprascapular nerve.
